title: Monday, 9th January, 2017

BE11:21am

Key Buys
Amundi, Man Group, Schroders, Provident Financial. Amundi offers scale and efficiency for a challenging secular backdrop. Man offers FX benefit, strong earnings recovery potential plus capital return. Schroders is a well-diversified forward-thinking asset manager with positive equity market gearing. Provident offers good EPS growth with an attractive yield at an undemanding rating, in our view.
Key Sells
Ashmore, Aberdeen, GAM, Hargreaves Lansdown, Jupiter. We see tough conditions remaining for EM-sensitive Ashmore and Aberdeen; and competitive and regulatory challenges outweighing the possible benefit of asset allocation shifts to equity and rising interest rates for Hargreaves Lansdown and Jupiter. GAM is priced for a recovery that could yet prove elusive, in our view.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Overall, while it is disappointing the group has come in below our own (£278m) and consensus expectations (£272m) for FY16 EBITA, it should not come as a major surprise given sporting results were unfavourable in December and this has been somewhat well flagged. We would also note sporting results only have an impact on short term profitability and should have no impact on valuation and the investment case. For us the key drivers of the investment case for William Hill remain: (i) the impending triennial review into gaming machines; (ii) the appointment of a permanent CEO; and (iii) showing evidence that it can turn around its online division. Clarity on all these issues is unlikely during Q1 and for this reason we continue to believe better value lies elsewhere in the sector. Our key Gaming sector picks for 2017 are Paddy Power Betfair, GVC and Playtech.

BE11:28am

So, Ladbrokes is due on the 18th Jan .....

11:31 am
BE11:31am

2016 has been a year to forget for WMH. The impact of the Q4 shortfall is that our 2016 EPS forecasts come down by 7%, with PBT down from £232.1m/22.4p to £216.9m/20.9p. However, this should have no bearing on the outcome for 2017, and management states that it continues to be confident "in a better performance in 2017". We see no reason to change our FY17 forecasts, at this stage, which remain at £248.7m/24.7p. Details are on Page 3.
However, the New Year comes with its own sizeable Black Swan, in the form of the Department of Culture, Media & Sport (DCMS) report into Machines stakes/prizes. The outcome will not be clear probably until late March. As we previously discussed, we estimate that a 25% hit to Machines revenues (probably approaching a worst case scenario) could knock 33% off WMH profits. Beyond that, WMH is missing a CEO, and there remains uncertainty over the turn-around in its recently underperforming Online business. Nonetheless, it also looks vulnerable to potential bid interest, having fended off an approach last year from 888/Rank.
Valuation

Given unchanged FY17 forecasts, the shares are still trading on a 2017 PER of 12.1x, an EV/Ebitda of 8.5x and offer a dividend yield of 4.2%. Operationally, it looks the weakest of the large listed Gambling companies, but with yield support and potential for bid speculation, the downside risk looks limited. We retain our 300p TP. HOLD.

PM11:32am

Following the passing of the Sapin 2 law at the end of 2016, the general rulebook of the AMF has now been adopted. The AMF has confirmed certain restrictions on electronic marketing of CFDs to retail clients in France. The key marketing restrictions do not impact the accounts that IG now offers to new clients in France, because IG's accounts provide a limited loss-by-position guarantee as required, and therefore also a guarantee of no negative balance. The AMF will also ban all electronic marketing involving FX and Binaries. As anticipated, the restrictions have no impact on the current client base.

IG Group Holdings PLC (IGG:LSE): Last: 527.91, down 3.09 (-0.58%), High: 540.00, Low: 526.00, Volume: 798.03k

I have a bit Liberum

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Following the adoption of restrictions on marketing activities in France (c.5% of active clients and total group revenue), IG Group stated this morning that it does not believe that the restrictions should have a material negative impact on its business in France in the short term. While the current client base is not affected, we do point out however that the cost of acquisition should increase considerably in the medium to long term. We note that the FCA's proposed changes to the marketing of CFDs and binaries remain the biggest risk to IG, and therefore in the absence of further clarity on the regulatory changes facing the industry, we maintain our U/R stance on the company.

PM11:35am

They are understandably cautious

PM11:36am

The Sapin 2 law, which was passed at the end of 2016 and enforces the new legislation, is very specific and stipulates that clients cannot lose more than their initial margin on a particular trade, i.e. a client’s gross account will not be able to subsidise what might be a losing position in one particular position. In other words, clients losses will be limited to the initial margin on a particular trade. According to IG, it is not impacted by these restrictions (post their recent change to limited loss accounts), since the accounts it provides are on a limited loss-by-position guarantee, and therefore they also guarantee no negative balance.

The regulation also bans all electronic marketing involving FX and Binaries. According to IG, "these restrictions have no impact on the current client base." We do however point out that this will increase the cost of acquisition considerably in the medium to long term.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

FCA's intentions remain the biggest risk to IG

PM11:36am

The consultation on the FCA's proposed changes to the to the marketing of CFDs and binaries is currently open and will conclude on 7 March 2017. In FY16, the UK contributed 51% of IG's total revenues. As a reminder, four major directives have been proposed which apply to CFDs and spread bets:

Risk warnings: Introduction of standard risk warnings and mandatory disclosures of profit-loss ratios on client accounts. - According to FCA research, 82% of clients lose money;
Bonuses: Preventing providers from using bonus benefits to encourage account opening or trading activity;
Leverage caps for new clients: Capping leverage at a max. of 1:25 for retail clients who have less than 12 months experience.
Maximum leverage Caps: Capping leverage at a max. of 1:50 for all retail clients
The statement went on to say, "The FCA also has concerns that binary bets pose investor protection risks and question whether binary bets meet a genuine investment need." It went on to state, "The FCA has also observed that binary bets are not transparent enough for investors to adequately value them, and have product features which are more akin to gambling products than investments."

In the absence of further clarity on the regulatory changes facing the industry, we maintain our U/R stance on IG.

And also off the back of Mike Fries saying some fairly anodyne things at a Barclays TMT conference on Friday.

BE11:49am

“One of the assets in Europe that we like are free-to-air broadcasters, because in Europe free-to-air broadcasters continue to dominate 70%, 80% of the viewership, they are the only real production engine in those countries, they have all the eyeballs, they have great reach. We've done a deal in Belgium, we've done a deal in Ireland, and those deals have worked out very well for us.”

…

“I don't want to overstate it to say that five years out, I'll be sitting here and we'll be owning free-to-air everywhere. We won't. But in certain markets, they can add reach, they can add great marketing capability. They give you access to content you're not otherwise buying because they're acquiring it or building it or growing it or making it. They give you an advertising hedge if you wanted. And so from that point of view, we're going to be opportunistic about it. I'm not sure I mentioned your question directly, but as you look at the approach we're taking on connect and play, the play component, you have to have the functionality and all the great content. And that means being strategic in each market with the content that's important to your consumers.”

BE11:49am

Liberum pushes ITV on this, as Liberum tends to.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Liberty Global owns 9.9% of ITV currently. The UK is probably the Western European market to which Liberty is paying the most attention at the moment. Its Project Lightning rollout aims to extend the reach of its pay-tv asset’s, Virgin Media, coverage from roughly half of the UK to roughly two-thirds. Given the comments above, owning ITV on top of Virgin Media seems to have a strong strategic rationale for Liberty, even before using ITV’s profits to utilise Virgin’s tax losses credits.

BE11:49am

There are a number of reasons we like ITV but a quick summary would include:

It has an attractive market leading position – ITV controls an estimated 45% of the UK TV advertising market and its audience for its main ITV1 channel has grown nearly 3% YTD putting it in a very good position to take share of the UK TV advertising market in 2017E.
It has attractive content assets – ITV has made a number of acquisitions in the content space and has built up its content portfolio. Globally, content in the UK and the US (and the Netherlands) has been seen as attractive to global broadcasters; these are all content markets where ITV has ownership of assets. With the increased demand for content, those companies that have credible content assets are likely to be seen as more valuable.
We have a positive view of the Free to Air Broadcasters in general, which is our most preferred media sector, as we believe its structural position is more secure than the consensus thinks.
It is attractively valued – on our estimates, the shares trade at just over 11.1x adjusted FY17E PE. It has limited gearing (we estimate that it will have £678m net debt at YE16E, or 0.7x net debt / EBITDA.

BE11:50am

BE11:54am

Genel Energy (GENL LN); SPEC. BUY; £2.70: Discovery at Peshkabir in Kurdistan – DNO (DNO NO) (not covered) announced an oil discovery in the Cretaceous horizon at Peshkabir. The well flowed 3.8 mbbl/d of 28 deg API oil on test from an oil interval in excess of 300 metres. Genel holds 25% WI in the field. Options to step-up the appraisal of the field are being considered, including a geological side-track in the central part of the Peshkabir structure or a third well. Early production through the Tawke facilities, located 12 km away, is also being considered. Market reaction: positive. While DNO has not provided any indication of the size of the discovery, we currently carry the overall prospect at 225 mmbbl gross resources in our valuation with a ReNAV of £0.12 per share (£0.49 per share unrisked). Further investment in Kurdistan remains contingent on receiving consistent and predictable payments.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

And RBC

BE11:55am

Operator DNO this morning announced that the Peshkabir-2 well, currently drilling on the Tawke PSC, has discovered oil in the Cretaceous horizon in the southern flank of the Peshkabir field (DNO 55%, Genel 25%). Peshkabir-2 (see exhibit) was spudded in October to target a Cretaceous horizon and appraise the previously discovered Jurassic reservoir, in a structure located between the Fishkabur terminal and the Tawke field.

We include upside/risk of +NOK1.40/-NOK0.63 per share for the (~150mmbbl) exploration/ (~100mmbbl) appraisal well in our NOK14.83/share DNO NAV, and upside/risk of +23p/-7p per share for the structure in our 227p/share Genel NAV. The well flowed at 3,800b/d of 28° API oil per day from an open hole test of a 170m interval; pressure data supported by observations of oil shows from cuttings and side wall cores indicate a Cretaceous oil interval in excess of 300m. We would expect a portion of this upside to be reflected in share prices today as the well is deepened to assess the deeper objective.

The well is expected to reach a TD of 3,500m and should be completed in the Jurassic by early February. The partners are considering a number of options to step up the appraisal of the new Cretaceous discovery, including a side-track into the central part of the Peshkabir structure or a third well. The Tawke partners will provide an update on the resource potential of both the Cretaceous and Jurassic horizons when operations conclude; Genel’s 24th January operating update is likely to come too soon, but we may learn more when DNO reports it FY16 results on the 9th February.

BE11:55am

BE11:58am

Sector view – we remain positive
We continue to see good upside in the UK housebuilders due to the combination of strong demographics, poor historic supply and consequent unprecedented Government support. One of the aspects of this support is a much increased supply of land which has resulted in lower costs and better margins. With sector dividend yields of 6-7% pa and net asset growth of 10-11% pa in 2017-18 we believe the sector should deliver 15-20% returns per year for investors. Our models assume only modest economic growth in CY17 and CY18 but this should be sufficient to see the sector grow turnover by 7-8% pa in 2017-18 with PBT growing slightly faster. With strong cash flow, long land banks and modest amounts of net debt the scope for high levels of dividends/capital returns is good. There will be some labour and material cost pressures in 2017-18 but we believe these will be compensated by some modest HPI, lower land costs and better overhead recovery.
The outlook for the traditional estate agents is not as positive due to the lack of stock and high levels of stamp duty which are both discouraging transactions. However, we expect hybrid agents such as Purplebricks to make further share gains as a growing number of consumers are attracted by a full estate agency service for a low fixed fee.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

It's 190 pages. One hundred. And. Ninety. Pages.

BE11:59am

In terms of companies covered ......

BE12:00pm

Stock views
We have Buy recommendations on the following stocks:
• Berkeley Group – One of our top picks. We think the group’s track record of creating value despite London housing cycles is well worth supporting especially as the fears about London are overplayed in our view.
• Countryside – The Partnerships business remains the real differentiator to the peer group and overall the group offers plenty of growth. We forecast PBT to nearly double over the next couple of years.
• Crest Nicholson – Crest is set to deliver a top quartile ROE and dividend yield, yet it is currently trading on a P/NAV below the sector average. A rare combination of attractive value and income.
• Galliford Try – While the hybrid model won’t appeal to all, we see good growth coming from all parts of the group over the next few years.
• Purplebricks – The dominant player in the hybrid estate agency industry and well placed to become the largest agent in the UK in the next few years. Growing revenues and low fixed costs should drive significant profit growth.
• Redrow – Despite having been the best performing housebuilder for the last two years we continue to see more upside from a business that likes to underpromise and over-deliver.
• Taylor Wimpey – A quality land bank with a good mix of strategic land should sustain margins ahead of the sector average. Currently offering the highest yield in the sector at c9%, the shares are undervalued in our view.
• Telford Homes – Its sector leading forward sales provides excellent visibility on profit delivery. This underpins the group’s output growth targets and we forecast PBT growth of c60% by March 2019.
• Watkin Jones – The forward sale model drives strong cash generation and high visibility on profits. The shares trade on a FY17 cash adjusted PE of just 7.2x and offer a double-digit free cash flow yield and 5.3% dividend yield.
We have Sell recommendations on the following stocks:
• Foxtons – We continue to believe that market share gains are being stymied by its high commission rates. We forecast no profit growth over the next two years and our 80p target price implies c20% downside.
• LSL – The group’s ‘profit per branch’ targets look increasingly unachievable. Against the backdrop of slowing transactions, pressure from fixed price agents and a proposed lettings fee ban, the risks to forecasts lie on the downside.

12:00 pm

Foxtons, Countrywide, are downgrades.

BE12:00pm
